subject: Programming
title: Backtracking
description: A fast breakdown of Backtracking for builders.

hook.text: Solving a Sudoku means trying a number, checking if it works, and undoing it if it doesn't.

buildup.text: Backtracking explores all possible solutions by trying options and retreating from dead ends.

discovery.text: It prunes impossible branches early, so it doesn't waste time on paths that can't lead to a solution.

twist.text: Without pruning, backtracking is just brute force. The smarts are in what you skip.

climax.text: Chess engines, constraint solvers, and puzzle games all rely on elegant backtracking.

punchline.text: Try, fail, undo, try again â€” systematically.

quiz.question: What makes backtracking faster than brute force?
